Introduction

Send comments on this topic.
Several unique features of flash memory make it ideal for embedded applications. These include its non-volatile nature, low power requirements, high density, and rugged nature. Flash memory is also versatile, capable of serving as a read-only memory for both the storage and execution of program code, as well as a disk drive for the storage of code and data files.

However, flash memory has several characteristics that make it difficult to use in some applications. These characteristics include its inability to overwrite data without a prior erase operation, its requirement for special programming algorithms, and a limited number of write/erase cycles over its lifetime.

Some flash memory technologies such as NAND, ship from the factory with bad blocks and may develop more of these bad blocks over time. The ability to dynamically correct errors and manage replacement blocks is crucial to the successful use of NAND flash parts.

Datalight FlashFX Tera makes flash memory appear as a standard high-performance disk drive to the operating system, maximizing the positive features of flash memory, while minimizing those features that make flash memory difficult to use. Applications can use standard disk drive access methods to read and write flash memory, with no modifications. The advanced features managed by FlashFX Tera, such as erase operations, fault tolerance, wear-leveling, and bad block management, are completely transparent to applications using FlashFX.

FlashFX Tera features

  • Patented (US Patent # 5860082) Variable Block Format (VBF), which provides efficient access to data in flash memory.
  • Patented (US Patent # 6260156) Bad Block Management (BBM), which provides an efficient mechanism to detect, correct, and manage bad areas found in NAND flash technology. The enhanced format capability of BBM automatically detects bad blocks and reserves a replacement block region on the flash array. BBM extends the effective life of NAND memory, allowing for robust storage in the case of memory region failures.
  • Fault-tolerance, guaranteeing atomic sector writes. Sectors are guaranteed to be either fully written or not touched if a power interruption occurs. This ensures a high level of data protection by means of automated write interruption recovery, which is critical for modern file systems. This protects low-level data structures to avoid losing data in harsh environments where power interruptions are common.
  • Wear-leveling algorithms, which extend the lifetime of the flash array. Flash memory must be erased before data can be changed. Each flash part has an erase zone size, which may vary from a few KB to 512KB or more. Wear-leveling algorithms ensure that erase zones are used evenly across the entire flash array. Wear-leveling is especially useful when large portions of the flash array are used for long-term code or data storage.
  • Supports multithreaded operations, allowing read requests to interrupt write and erase operations, which can be time-consuming on many types of flash. This makes FlashFX Tera ideal for streaming media applications such as state-of-the-art cell phones and digital cameras.
  • On multithreaded operating systems, flash compaction may be done in the background, during idle time, greatly improving performance.
  • Source code and documentation necessary to integrate FlashFX Tera into a wide range of environments. The flash array may be paged into system address space, accessed through a small I/O address, or mapped entirely into the CPU's extended or protected address space.
  • The ability to run from ROM.
  • Support for flash arrays of up to 2TB in size.
  • High density NAND support. FlashFX Tera provides optimal support for both today's and tomorrow's NAND parts, including write-once-sequentially memory.
  • Auto-detection of specific flash parts and the size of the flash array in the Flash Memory Services Layer (FMSL).

About This Manual

The level of coverage provided in this manual assumes that you are proficient in developing software in C. You must also be aware of the hardware mechanisms used to access the flash array within your target system. Finally, if a Flash Interface Module (FIM) or NAND Technology Module (NTM) is not included in this kit for the particular type, organization, or family of flash device used in your target system, you'll need to be familiar with the requirements for reading, writing, and erasing that flash device so you can create a custom FIM or NTM.

What's in the FlashFX Tera SDK

The FlashFX Tera SDK provides the necessary source code and direction to assist in customizing FlashFX Tera for a given environment. There are various portions of the product that must be configured or tailored to the CPU, flash memory, and environment in general.

The SDK consists of the following items

  • The ANSI C source code for FlashFX Tera.
  • This SDK Developer's Guide documentation.
  • Sample applications and tools.
Some parts of the FlashFX Tera SDK may be supplied in obfuscated form. These parts do not need to be modified in the vast majority of cases. If full, unobfuscated source code is necessary, contact Datalight to obtain the FlashFX Tera Core Source Kit, described below.

Other Datalight Products

The FlashFX Tera Core Source Kit

The FlashFX Tera Core Source Kit contains unobfuscated source code for those portions of the FlashFX Tera SDK that are normally obfuscated. The Core Source Kit is designed to be installed over the top of a FlashFX Tera SDK. The Core Source Kit is ideal for those users who need the full source code for FlashFX Tera in order to customize the FlashFX Tera core functionality, or for code escrow purposes.

The Datalight Reliance Nitro File System

FlashFX Tera provides a general block device driver interface to flash memory that can be used by virtually any file system. While having a robust block device driver, such as FlashFX Tera, is invaluable in an embedded system, the block device driver only guarantees the integrity of individual disk sectors, and cannot guarantee the integrity of the logical structures used by the file system that resides on top of it.

Datalight Reliance Nitro is a transactional file system for embedded devices that can be used with any standard block device driver, of course, including FlashFX Tera. Unlike typical file systems often found in embedded devices, such as the FAT file system, Reliance Nitro is specifically designed for use in the embedded marketplace. As such, it is designed with the following characteristics in mind:

1 - File system integrity is maintained at all times, regardless of power loss scenarios.
2 - Fast boot-up times are critical in an embedded device, therefore, requiring a chkdsk or scandisk operation at system startup is not acceptable – even if power was lost during the previous session.
3 - Performance is important in an embedded system where users expect low response times.
4 - Low resource usage is often critical in embedded systems that have predetermined hardware and software characteristics.

Datalight Reliance Nitro is specifically designed to achieve these goals and is designed to work seamlessly with FlashFX Tera, as well as any standard block device.
